title-group.article-title: Peripheral Arterial Disease Assessment With Photoplethysmography and Continuous-Wave Doppler Ultrasound in Addition to Ankle-Brachial Index May Loss Time and Funds

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Seoul National University College of Medicine, Seoul, South Korea
2Department of Orthopedic Surgery, Boramae Medical Center, Seoul National University College of Medicine, Seoul, South Korea
3Department of Orthopedic Surgery, Seoul National University, Bundang Hospital, Seongnam, South Korea

author-notes.corresp: Dong Yeon Lee, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Seoul National University Hospital, 28 Yeongeon-dong Jongno-gu, Seoul 110-744, South Korea. Email: leedy@snu.ac.kr

body.p: We recently evaluated the sensitivity and specificity of ankle-brachial index (ABI), photoplethysmography (PPG), and continuous-wave Doppler ultrasound (CWD) in the detection of anatomically stenotic peripheral arterial disease (PAD). 1 The ABI showed significantly decreased sensitivity especially in stenosis below the trifurcation level. Both PPG and CWD were complementary to the ABI in these groups of patients. 1

We agree with Dr Demirkol that concomitant PPG and CWD involves both additional cost and time. 2 However, with progress of interventional procedures in patients with PAD, we believe that proper management in patients with PAD before they develop critical limb ischemia can be helpful. 3 So, we suggest a complimentary test to overcome well-known limitations of the ABI test. However, using specialized equipment which is available worldwide, PPG and CWD can be checked concomitantly with ABI in one continuous session. Although its benefit should be further evaluated, we showed in this article that they were worthy as tests to compliment the ABI.

As for ABI, we measured blood pressure (BP) using Doppler as mentioned in the article in a standardized manner. However, although we did have BP data, we did not think that the absolute values of BP would add any useful information.
